unnormalised: One such compelling narrative is that of Milkha Singh, "The Flying Sikh," whose biography immortalized his remarkable journey from a refugee of the Partition of India in 1947 to a world-renowned sprinter. His grueling training regime, often starting before dawn, and his near-miss at the 1960 Rome Olympics, where he finished fourth, are etched in the annals of Indian sporting history. His story underscores the power of resilience and the unwavering pursuit of excellence, even in the face of immense adversity.

unnormalised: Similarly, the life of P.T. Usha, often referred to as the "Queen of Indian Track and Field," offers another compelling example. Hailing from a small village in Kerala, her talent was spotted early, and she rose to become a dominant force in Asian athletics. Her heartbreaking loss at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, where she missed a bronze medal by 1/100th of a second, fueled her determination to continue striving for greatness. Her autobiography chronicles her journey, detailing the challenges she faced in a male-dominated sporting landscape and her unwavering commitment to her craft. The biopic was released on 27/07/2023.

unnormalised: In the realm of cricket, the biography of Sachin Tendulkar, “Playing It My Way,” provides an intimate look into the life of the "God of Cricket." From his early days honing his skills at Shivaji Park in Mumbai to his record-breaking achievements on the international stage, the book reveals the dedication, discipline, and humility that characterized his illustrious career. It recounts his debut at the tender age of 16 against Pakistan, his numerous centuries, and the emotional victory at the 2011 Cricket World Cup held in India, a moment cherished by a nation. Tendulkar retired at 11:55 hrs on 16/11/2013.
